  "overview": "The purpose and intent of this measure is to, beginning January 1, 2026, require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy. [CHUNK_73] [CHUNK_74] This measure will impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians.   "appropriations": "The provided legislative documents do not contain any specific appropriations for this measure.   "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided documents do not contain financial projections or a detailed cost estimation methodology for this measure.   "agency_impact": "The Board of Pharmacy will be required to register pharmacy technicians and issue a certificate of registration starting January 1, 2026. [CHUNK_73] [CHUNK_74] The Board of Pharmacy voted unanimously to support this measure. [CHUNK_1] The Board recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance. [CHUNK_3]",
  "economic_impact": "Your Committee finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. [CHUNK_75] [CHUNK_76] This measure provides the regulatory oversight needed to ensure that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision.   "policy_impact": "This measure builds upon Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session, which allows pharmacy technicians to administer immunizations and vaccinations. [CHUNK_20] [CHUNK_29] [CHUNK_46] [CHUNK_61] The bill addresses a significant gap, as Hawai‘i is the only state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians.   "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The provided documents do not contain a six-year fiscal projection for this measure. [CHUNK_21] [CHUNK_47] [CHUNK_62] [CHUNK_70] The creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is noted as an essential step forward, but any associated administrative or technology costs are not specified in the documents.   "operating_revenue_impact": "The legislative documents provided for this version of the bill do not indicate any impact on operating revenues. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] Therefore, no changes to the state's operating revenue streams are anticipated based on the current documents. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not indicate any capital expenditures are required for this measure.   "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The provided documents do not specify any ongoing fiscal obligations after a six-year period. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] The testimony suggests it is a long-term prudent investment in the pharmacy workforce, but does not quantify annual operating costs.   "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The primary change from the previous fiscal note is the absence of specific financial details in the current source documents. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] Additionally, the previous note mentioned an effective date of December 31, 2050, which is not mentioned in the current documents. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "fte_positions": "The provided legislative documents and testimonies for H.B. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1 do not specify the addition or modification of any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] There is no mention of new staffing being required by the Board of Pharmacy to implement or manage the registration program. [CHUNK_1] [CHUNK_74] The bill's focus is on establishing the regulatory requirements and duties for pharmacy technicians and pharmacists. [CHUNK_73] [CHUNK_74]",
  "appropriations_changes": "Similar to the previous version, the current version of the bill does not contain any appropriations. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] However, unlike the documents supporting the previous fiscal note, the current documents do not establish an alternative funding mechanism through registration fees. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] Therefore, no appropriations or funding sources are specified in this version. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "There is a significant change in funding sources between the versions. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] The previous fiscal note was based on documents that established a funding source through registration fees and fines. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] The current documents for H.B. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1 do not specify any method of funding. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "department_impact": "The department impacted by this measure remains the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, under which the Board of Pharmacy operates. [CHUNK_8] [CHUNK_74] This is consistent with the previous version of the bill. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] The Board of Pharmacy has provided testimony in support of the measure. [CHUNK_1]",
  "reports_required": "The reporting requirements appear consistent with the previous version. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] The bill imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians to the Board of Pharmacy. [CHUNK_74] The provided documents do not specify new or modified reports to the legislature. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "pilot_program": "This measure does not create a pilot program. [CHUNK_73] It establishes a permanent registration requirement for pharmacy technicians beginning January 1, 2026. [CHUNK_73] This initiative is intended to align Hawai‘i with national pharmacy technician regulation standards on an ongoing basis. [CHUNK_22] [CHUNK_28] [CHUNK_63]",
  "sunset_date": "The provided documents for H.B. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1 do not contain a sunset date. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] This differs from the previous fiscal note, which noted a placeholder effective date of December 31, 2050, that was inserted to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72]",
  "effective_date": "The provided documents do not specify an effective date for the Act itself. [CHUNK_0] [CHUNK_72] However, the bill specifies that the requirement for pharmacy technicians to be registered shall begin on January 1, 2026. [CHUNK_73]"

chunk_details.chunk_text: Testimony of the Board of Pharmacy Before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Thursday, March 27, 2025 9:30 a.m. Conference Room 229 and Videoconference On the following measure: H. B. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair Keohokalole and Members of the Committee: My name is

Chair Keohokalole and Members of the Committee: My name is James Skizewski, Executive Officer of the Board of Pharmacy (Board). The Board voted unanimously to support this measure. The purpose of this bill beginning 1/1/2026 is to: (1) require pharmacy technicians to be registered; (2) impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge

technicians to be registered; (2) impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. The Board supports this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. The Board recently

this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. The Board recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance. The group noted the need to recognize national certifications provided by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while

by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while still acknowledging the presence of local technicians who have received extensive on the job training. The Board agreed that a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the

regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the scope of practice to technicians that are nationally certified should also be recognized. The expansion should include allowances such as those provided in Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill.

Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI‘I SYSTEM ʻŌNAEHANA KULANUI O HAWAIʻI Legislative Testimony Hōʻike Manaʻo I Mua O Ka ʻAhaʻōlelo _____________________________________________________________ Testimony Presented Before the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Thursday, March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. By Bonnie Irwin, Chancellor

March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. By Bonnie Irwin, Chancellor and Rae Matsumoto, Dean Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo HB 72 HD2 SD1 – RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit

of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony on HB 72 HD2 SD1. The University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo (UH Hilo) supports HB 72 HD2 SD1, which will require the registration of pharmacy technicians through the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals

of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist, and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies. Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important

practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important for supporting public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to

regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. We would like to emphasize that pharmacy technicians are professionals and represent a distinct category from pharmacy interns who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As

who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As career professionals in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians perform functions under the supervision of pharmacists and may include roles such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional

such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care workforce, the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify

by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify in support of HB 72 HD2 SD1. Comments: Testimony for HB72: A bill to mandate pharmacy technician registration within the DCCA COMMITTEE ON COMMERCE AND CONSUMER PROTECTION March 27. 2025 Testimony in SUPPORT of HB72 To the Honorable Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee, As a pharmacist practicing in Hawai‘i, I strongly support

Committee, As a pharmacist practicing in Hawai‘i, I strongly support HB72, which seeks to establish critical regulations for pharmacy technicians in our state. Pharmacy technicians are essential in performing the following tasks that are critical to the workflow of the pharmacy Hawai‘i is the ONLY state in the nation without

pharmacy Hawai‘i is the ONLY state in the nation without an active, managed list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe preparation and delivery of medications, and this initiative

the safe preparation and delivery of medications, and this initiative will serve as the backbone for consistent standards of training and competency across the profession. Additionally, the creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond

a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. Beyond enhancing patient safety, HB72 will lay the foundation for pharmacy technicians in Hawai‘i to expand their scope of practice in the future. Across the country, pharmacy technicians are taking on advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication

advanced roles, such as administering immunizations and assisting with medication management. Without regulation, Hawai‘i cannot adapt to these changes and risks falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and

represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. I urge the Committee to support HB72 and help Hawai‘i align with national pharmacy technician regulation standards to strengthen pharmacy practice in our state. Suite 1400 F 808-533-4945 Honolulu, HI 96813 DATE: March 25, 2025 TO: Senator Jarrett Keohokalole Chair, Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection Senator Carol Fukunaga Vice Chair, Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection FROM: Tiffany Yajima RE: H.B. 72, HD2, SD1 – Relating to Pharmacy Decision Making Hearing Date: Thursday,

SD1 – Relating to Pharmacy Decision Making Hearing Date: Thursday, March 27, 2025 at 9:30 a.m. Conference Room: 229 Dear Chair Keohokalole, Vice Chair Fukunaga, and Members of the Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection: Walgreens submits this testimony in support of H.B. 72, HD2, SD1, which requires pharmacy technicians

support of H.B. 72, HD2, SD1, which requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the state. Walgreen Co. (“Walgreens”) operates stores at more than 9,000 locations in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In Hawaii, Walgreens has 13 stores on the islands of Oahu and Maui.

has 13 stores on the islands of Oahu and Maui. Walgreens supports this measure which adopts a definition of “auxiliary personnel” for personnel such as cashiers whose responsibilities are purely clerical in nature, clarifies the specific duties of a pharmacy technician, clarifies a pharmacist’s supervision of a technician, establishes the

technician, clarifies a pharmacist’s supervision of a technician, establishes the specific functions of a pharmacy technician in statute, and exempts this measure from the requirements of a sunrise analysis due to the exigent need for technician regulation. Pharmacy technicians play an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a

an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a range of tasks that allow pharmacists to focus on more complex responsibilities like patient consultations and clinical services. For example, pharmacy technicians can assist pharmacists with the preparation, dispensing, and managing of patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling

managing of patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling prescriptions, labeling and packaging medications, managing medication inventory, and performing administrative duties such as record-keeping and insurance processing. is one of two states that do not require any sort of certification or registration. Registration would be the first step towards regulating the employees who work in Hawaii’s pharmacies. techs have expanded, and with this comes increased responsibilities and requirements. This bill will also require the pharmacist in charge to report violations conducted by registered technicians. one pharmacy to another. Pharmacy technicians have access to controlled substances. it will protect the pharmacy patients of Hawaii by taking this initial step toward regulating the pharmacy technicians. overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while still acknowledging the presence of local technicians who have received extensive on the job training. regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the scope of practice to technicians that are nationally certified should also be recognized. of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony on HB 72 HD2 SD1. The University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo (UH Hilo) supports HB 72 HD2 SD1, which will require the registration of pharmacy technicians through the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist, and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies. Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important

practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important for supporting public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to

regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. We would like to emphasize that pharmacy technicians are professionals and represent a distinct category from pharmacy interns who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As

who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As career professionals in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians perform functions under the supervision of pharmacists and may include roles such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional

such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care workforce, the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify

by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify in support of HB 72 HD2 SD1. an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a range of tasks that allow pharmacists to focus on more complex responsibilities like patient consultations and clinical services.
